legacyCollection.name: Europe
legacyCollection.longDescription: The latest news, analysis and investigations from Europe.

headline.default: France’s New Cabinet Mixes Fresh and Familiar, Hinting at Macron’s Priorities

node.summary: President Emmanuel Macron’s newly announced government combines continuity with change, as first-term veterans were joined by newcomers in top positions at the foreign and education ministries.

headline.default: Russia Hustles to Recruit Soldiers and Halts Gas Supplies to Finland

bylines.renderedRepresentation: By Katrin Bennhold, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Andrew E. Kramer

node.summary: The war has evolved into something of a stalemate that has seriously depleted Russia’s conventional war capabilities, even as it has made some gains.

headline.default: Comment une banque française a fait main basse sur Haïti

bylines.renderedRepresentation: By Matt Apuzzo, Constant Méheut, Selam Gebrekidan and Catherine Porter

node.summary: À la fin du 19e siècle, le Crédit Industriel et Commercial a soutiré des millions à Haïti. Le Times a retracé l’histoire de cette opération — et son coût pour Haïti.

headline.default: U.S. Company Supplying Russian Military Seeks Exit, Caught Between Sanctions and Kremlin

node.summary: Arconic runs a huge Russian metal plant, bought in an era of cooperation between the U.S. and Russia. Now it is struggling, after years of increasing Russian military aggression.

headline.default: How Russia Uses Show Trials to Punish Putin’s Enemies

node.summary: Moscow may label the Azov fighters who defended the Mariupol steel plant as terrorists — raising the prospect of a high-profile trial. The Kremlin has a long tradition of using the courts for political goals.

headline.default: BBC Allowed to Publish Accusations of Abuse Against MI5 Agent

node.summary: The news organization found that evidence suggested an agent for the domestic intelligence agency had a history of right-wing extremism and was abusive toward women, but it wasn’t allowed to fully identify him.

headline.default: Washington Warns Britain to Temper Its Spat With E.U. Over Northern Ireland

node.summary: A senior U.S. diplomat urged London and Brussels to discreetly resolve their disputes, citing the need to unify the West behind Ukraine amid Russia’s onslaught.

headline.default: What Is Monkeypox?

node.summary: There have been dozens of cases reported in recent weeks among populations not typically vulnerable to the disease.

headline.default: George Grosz, Sharp-Eyed Berlin Observer, Comes Home

node.summary: A new museum in a converted gas station presents the work of one of the best-known artists of Weimar-era Germany.

headline.default: Lyon’s Women Bridge Eras in a Changing Champions League

node.summary: The arrival of new money in women’s soccer has come at a cost in Europe: It has separated the sport from its past.

headline.default: U.N. Human Rights Chief to Make First Trip to China Since 2005

node.summary: Rights groups say Michelle Bachelet’s trip, including a visit to the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, where Beijing has cracked down on the Uyghur minority, will be a test of her office’s credibility.

headline.default: Russia Is Weaponizing Global Food Supply in Ukraine War, Blinken Says

node.summary: In a meeting led by U.S. Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, United Nations officials warned that the war in Ukraine has exacerbated a global hunger crisis already strained by the pandemic and climate change.

headline.default: Italy Says Ancient Statue in U.S. Museum Was Stolen, Not Lost at Sea

node.summary: A court near Pompeii has ordered the return of a treasured classical antiquity that was purchased by the Minneapolis Institute of Art almost four decades ago.

headline.default: In Milan, an Iconic Stadium Isn’t Going Down Without a Fight

node.summary: The soccer teams that share the San Siro, which has hosted two World Cups and four European finals, want to replace it with a more modern arena. Not everyone is ready to see it go.

headline.default: A Weak Euro Heads to an Uncomfortable Milestone: Parity With the Dollar

node.summary: The euro hasn’t fallen below the one-to-one exchange rate with the U.S. dollar for two decades. But as economic risks grow, more analysts predict deeper lows for the shared currency.

headline.default: Four Ways to Understand the $54 Billion in U.S. Spending on Ukraine

bylines.renderedRepresentation: By Bianca Pallaro and Alicia Parlapiano

node.summary: It’s the most annual assistance given by the U.S. to a country in the last decade.

headline.default: Your Friday Briefing

node.summary: Hungary’s thirst for Russian oil.

headline.default: A Russian rock singer was charged after condemning the Ukraine war at a concert.

node.summary: The singer made the comments less than three months after Russia enacted a law that would punish spreading “false information” about its invasion.

headline.default: Nuevas pruebas muestran cómo unos soldados rusos ejecutaron hombres en Bucha

bylines.renderedRepresentation: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Evan Hill, Malachy Browne and David Botti

node.summary: El relato de unos testigos y videos obtenidos por The New York Times muestran cómo los paracaidistas rusos ejecutaron al menos a ocho hombres ucranianos en un suburbio de Kiev el 4 de marzo, un posible crimen de guerra.

headline.default: Moscow Moves to Russify Seized Ukraine Land, Signaling Annexation

bylines.renderedRepresentation: By Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Norimitsu Onishi

node.summary: The territory occupied by Russian forces so far in the three-month-old invasion deserves “a worthy place in our Russian family,” a Kremlin official who toured the region said.
